segments.text: Many weeks have passed since then.
Throughout the journey back to the base he held her hand.
Occasionally he would caress her cheek, repeatedly kiss the inside of her hand, just like that first time.
But the moment they arrived at the base it was as if they had entered a madhouse.
Even the commander forgot how curious he had been.

It turned out that the mysterious operation was indeed about to take place, and that same day, Dan went down again to that remote place in the Judean Desert for another training session, and to revisit everything they had practiced the previous time.
For two weeks, she didn't see him at all, and then they returned, and he politely asked the commander to leave them alone in his office.
She felt herself blush, embarrassed by the commander.
I had no choice, he explained to her.
We're leaving tonight, and I had to say goodbye to you.
He dawned a serious expression.
Look, there are things I would love to tell you and share, but I simply can't say anything.
I can only tell you that it's going to be long, very long.
And I ask that you understand and try not to worry.
It's not related to the operation, it's something else.
I thought this whole thing would take less time and that we'd have much more time together.
I'll come back to you, and when I return, I can explain.
Please don't disappear on me."
There was something almost pleading in his tone.

He gave her that same serious, penetrating look, as if trying to memorize every feature of her face, embraced her tightly, kissed her lips for a long time, and then abruptly moved away from her, said bye, turned, and left.
She remained stunned for a long time in the commander's office, trying to swallow the lung forming in her throat, to overcome the tears welling in her eyes and the fear that invaded her heart.
Only then did she carefully open the door directly in front of the commander who stood at the entrance, as if waiting for her to decide when to open it.
He didn't say a word, but the way he looked at her made it clear that he understood.
Thus began long, nearly sleepless nights, filled with worry, ignorance, because everything was so secretive, and no one said a word to her.
The commander went to the central base time and time again, and every time he returned, it seemed to her that the crease between his eyes deepened even more.
Sometimes in a moment of grace, he would tell her, I'm sorry, but I really can't say anything.
and he always added at the end, don't worry.
But how could she not worry?
Although she could have gone home, she stayed at the base for two weekends because she couldn't bear the thought that maybe they would return and she wouldn't be there.
And then something very strange happened.
The group of soldiers who went with him on that secretive mission returned one night by helicopter, landing them near the base, but without Dan.
A chill settled in the pit of her stomach, and she looked with a questioning, worried gaze at the commander.
He approached her and whispered in her ear alone.
He's okay, but he won't be back here anytime soon.
The next day, he called her in for a talk.
There's no point in you staying here for nothing.
Go home and rest, he told her.
Take some leaves and try to catch up on sleep.
Believe me, you can sleep peacefully, at least for now.
As she made her way home by bus, the thought passed through her mind to maybe visit mom Naomi and dad David at Bate Yanai, but she had no idea what they knew, if anything.
It had been several months since she last saw them, and perhaps it was best not to complicate an already complicated situation.
The bus was packed, it was hot and suffocating, and she felt increasingly nauseated.
She managed to hold back, but as soon as she got off, she moved aside and vomited her soul out.
Strange, she thought to herself.
It wasn't as if she ate much.
She hardly had an appetite due to stress and worry.
And maybe it really was the stress, or it was related to the illness she had experienced.
But even then, nearly three months had passed.
In any case, the moment she threw up, she felt much better.
She took deep breaths, boarded the inner bus line in the community, and got off at the stop for the pink house.
Immediately, she began occupying herself without pause.
She went into a cleaning frenzy, tidied the rooms, made her way to the neighborhood grocery store, filled the fridge, and started a stew on the stove.
Afterwards, she chopped a salad, set the table for three.
almost hoping in her heart that one of the tenants would join her at the table when they realized she was there.
The last thing she needed at that moment was to sit and eat alone.
Until the stew was ready, she sat at the piano seeking comfort from its keys.
Dream a little dream for me, she asked with her fingers.
Quietly, almost sadly, she played that optimistic love song as if trying to connect with Dan at least in her dreams.
Say nighty-night and kiss me.
Just hold me tight and tell me you'll miss me, while I'm alone and blue as can be.
Dream a little dream of me."
When the song ended, she quietly closed the piano lid, and just as if on cue, she heard Danny the doctor's sports car stop in the parking lot.
Not a minute later, he stood before her in full stature, smiling a wide smile.
How wonderful you're here.
I can already smell something cooking.
And I smell the scent of horses, she laughed.
Better go wash up.
Anyway, it'll be another half-hour before it's ready."
He chuckled back at her and made his way to the rooms.
Half an hour later, he returned and sat down beside her at the table, not before pouring them both wine.
He raised the glass with her and said as he usually did, to the prettiest girl in the garden, then suddenly gazed at her inquisitively and asked, What's wrong?
Are you sad?
Tired?
Why are you so quiet?
She raised her eyes to him, not understanding why tears welled up in them.
Nothing, she said, I'm just worried and tired because I haven't slept properly in days, and it's probably all of it together.
Is it related to Dan, whom I met here a few months ago?
She didn't answer, just nodded.
Look, he told her, we'll finish eating and you'll simply get into bed and have a good sleep.
When you wake up, things will look a bit different.
I promise.
She gave him a faint smile.
The idea sounded wonderful to her.
She just wondered if she'd really be able to fall asleep.
Maybe exhaustion would overcome her.
They ate in silence.
She reached for her wine glass, took a small sip from it and within a moment felt a terrible nausea.
She closed her eyes, trying to overcome the nausea that rose within her.
And when she couldn't, she abruptly got up, ran to the bathroom and vomited her soul out.
She washed her face and intended to leave with a sense of relief.
only to find the doctor standing at the entrance.
You're completely pale, he said, concerned.
What's wrong with you?
He placed a hand on her forehead.
You don't have a fever.
I hope you're not coming down with some kind of flu or something.
You really should get into bed.
Go.
I'll clear up and close up after myself.
He was like an older brother to her.
Perhaps more than that.
He knew her secrets, knew her inside.
and at times worried about what would become of her with this house.
But he was also very proud of her courage, her dedication, and her immense responsibility in embarking on this adventure.
She felt completely safe letting him close up the dining room, knowing he would wash the dishes and leave everything clean and tidy.
She wasn't used to feeling unwell.
That one time she was so ill was after years of not being sick.
Since Lucy's illness,
She'd kept away from any thoughts of illness.
Now her unease was accompanied by fear.
She remembered that she had thrown up twice on the base.
And then when she got off the bus and here it was happening again.
But the moment she vomited, she felt better and everything returned to normal.
Maybe something in her stomach, maybe an ulcer.
Once she read that it could be caused by stress and anxiety, she got into her bed, didn't even try to read a line from the book beside her.
Anne in an instant succumbed to deep sleep.
The next day she woke up only at eight in the morning.
A quick calculation showed she had slept almost 12 hours.
She felt hunger creeping at the bottom of her stomach.
No wonder she thought she left her dinner in the bathroom and since then nothing had crossed her lips.
After she showered and got dressed, she made her way to the dining room.
She immediately noticed that its door was open.
The doctor had arrived before her.
She found him at the table, eating breakfast he had prepared for himself.
I can't believe it, he said.
The girl who wakes up with the bird sleeps till eight in the morning.
You must have really needed it.
How are you feeling?
I'm perfectly fine.
Just starving," she replied.
She sat down beside him and spread some cheese on a slice of bread from the basket.
She smiled at him, feeling better.
Apparently, everything was related to her lack of sleep.
Shall I make you an omelet?
He asked, We've got our rolls mixed up a bit, haven't we?
She laughed.
It's OK, I'll make it myself.
She got up, made herself an omelet, poured coffee for both of them, and sat back down to eat.
Why are you still here?
She inquired.
I'm headed to Haifa today, so I wasn't in a hurry.
I wanted to see if you're OK.
I was a bit worried.
As soon as she finished eating, she hadn't even managed to sip the coffee, and she already rushed back to the bathroom and vomited.
She washed her face and felt everything returning to normal, as if nothing had happened.
When she came back to the table, she found him looking at her intently, not speaking.
Tell me, could you be pregnant?
He suddenly asked.
She was stunned by his question.
Dear God, the possibility hadn't even crossed her mind.
The last time and almost the only time she had been with Dan was when she was sick.
And since then, almost three months had passed.
But now that the question was out in the open, she couldn't dismiss the possibility.
Her experience in such matters was so limited, she only knew they had been together repeatedly during those two intensely emotional days.
She raised her face to the doctor and in their typical honesty said to him, I don't know, but it's possible.
And if so, it happened almost three months ago.
These bouts of vomiting look exactly like pregnancy.
Aside from the vomiting, you're entirely fine.
No fever, no stomach aches.
It's a bit strange.
I'm going to ask you an embarrassing question.
Do you feel like your breasts have grown?
Instinctively, she placed her hands on them without any inhibitions in front of him, and it indeed seemed to her, suddenly, as if her small breasts had filled out a bit.
but she wasn't entirely sure of that.
Okay, he said, wait a moment.
He got up and went to his car, returning with a plastic container with a lid.
Go on, do a bit of pee in it.
He requested, I'll take it with me and by tomorrow we'll know exactly what's happening.
She got up and complied with his request, handing the half-filled container back to him, looking at him silently.
You'll call me once you know.
I'm on leave, not going back to the army in the coming days.
I'll call, he said, gathered his things and the container and left.
A whirlwind of thoughts spun in her head.
What if she is?
What can she do?
And Dan, where did he disappear to?
And for how long?
How will she know what he thinks about it?
She missed him so much, knowing what had developed between them was deep, special, and very warm.
Undoubtedly, this was love.
But under the existing circumstances at that moment, she wasn't sure at all that he would be happy about the possibility of becoming a father.
She herself had no plans to settle down now.
It all just happened a bit too quickly and too early.

She was supposed to be released from the army in four months, and all her focus was on the pink house, filling the rooms with tenants with breakfast and dinner, and maybe, maybe, in the meantime, also study something through correspondence.
Well, she tried to reassure.
herself.
Maybe it's all just a false alarm.
The doctor made his way north, lost in odds.
This girl has a very warm place in his heart, and he often felt he had to watch over her, as if he owed it to Lucy.
Until yesterday, he hadn't seen her in three weeks, because she hadn't come home.
Last time, he activated the sprinklers in the garden, so the lawn wouldn't turn yellow, and the flowers she some tenderly cared for wouldn't wither.
He was supposed to move to another area to take care of farmers' cows and horses in the north of the country.
But he had asked to stay a few more months until she was discharged so he could be by her side and maybe also help her if she had to return the pink house to Yehuda.
Now, perhaps the situation had become complicated.
She isn't careless, and he knows that if it happened, deep feelings are involved.
He met Dan, and if it's him, then he has a great deal of respect for him, based on the first impression he got.
She deserves someone like him, someone who knows how to appreciate her depth.
He suddenly remembered the letter he wrote to her a year and a half ago after she had to leave her pink house.
He wondered if she had even received it and read it.
I'm getting ahead of myself, he thought.
Maybe it's not that at all.
He noticed the black circles around her eyes, apparently the result of lack of sleep, and remembered she had told him she was worried.
Perhaps Dan is involved in some secret operation.
He decided to check with his former commander if he knew something.
As if the large solitude she lives in, raising herself, wasn't enough, now she needs to worry so much.
At the entrance to Haifa, he directed his vehicle towards the lab, where Shosh, his neighbor, worked.
He left her the urine cup and requested an urgent test.
Got yourself into trouble?
She asked with a smile.
Maybe he smiled back.
Call me when you have an answer.
